definitions.definition: to give freedom or free movement to someone or something:
examples: He was released from prison after serving two years of a five-year sentence.

definitions.definition: to move a device from a fixed position to allow it to move freely:
examples: He released the handbrake and the car jumped forwards.

definitions.definition: to fire a bomb or a missile (= flying weapon), or to allow it to fall:
examples: The plane released its bombs at 10,000 feet.

definitions.definition: to allow a substance to flow out from somewhere:
examples: Coal power stations release sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere.

definitions.definition: to express a feeling that you have been trying not to show:
examples: He punched the pillow in an effort to release his anger.

definitions.definition: an occasion when someone is allowed to leave prison, etc.:
examples: Her early release from prison led to a demonstration.

definitions.definition: the act of flowing out from somewhere:
examples: The accident caused the release of radioactivity into the atmosphere.

definitions.definition: a feeling that you are free from something unpleasant:
examples: I noticed a release of tension when he left the room.
